name: building construction, luxury hotel | building, luxury hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21257/documentation

This dataset represents a tourist accommodation facility classed as a luxury hotel (comfort category 5*), located in Campinas, SP, Brazil. It was first opened in 1999 as a brand new resort complex. The complex has capacity to host 1000 people and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): suites with one double bed (453) and suites with two double beds (47). These rooms are distributed among 5 different buildings that are surronded by 7 pools, a gym, a spa, kids area and four conference areas. The laundry is outsourced. The hotel occupies a total area of 58618,2 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is estimated to be 58%, based on Rio de Janeiro"s average occupancy for luxury hotels (Source: Anuário Estatístico da Taxa de Ocupação Hoteleira da Cidade do Rio de Janeiro. ABIH-RJ, 2016) which is equal to 211700 guest nights per year. The load bearing structure of hotel buildings is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork.

This dataset is modelled to include the inputs for the construction of a hotel building. This includes:energy and water used in construction, land transformation, building structure and outer building shell, foundations, inner walls, roofs, ceiling and windows, doors, floors, finishing and painting, bathroom equipment. Activities include hotel building construction with lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. Maintenance is included only through the consideration of the lifetime of the different exchanges. For example, windows are assumed to have a lifetime of 35 years, therefore the exchange amount is multiplied by 75years / 35 years=2.14.

Activities end with 1 unit of hostel building, including maintenance. Due to data availability, the following building construction processes have been excluded: mirror, urinary, shower, cables, gutter, drains, ventilation.
category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is based in Campinas, SP, Brazil
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The level of technology is considered current. The load bearing structure of hotel buildings is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of construction, the amounts of input material are calculated based on usage across all instances within the hotel building.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Combined of all instances of use across the building structure, walls and floor (5.4E+05m3). Assumed thickness of floor concrete of 225 mm, Insulation 2011. Thermafloor TF70. INSULATION FOR SOLID CONCRETE AND SUSPENDED GROUND FLOORS. Available from http://kingspaninsulation.co.uk/getattachment/5fdd04b2-e58e-4622-97bb-5861799ab02a/Thermafloor-TF70-pdf.pdf Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout.

Additionally the concrete for foundations is account for (5868m3). Estimated value based on the hotel area. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste concrete.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. No data but based on 500 apartments and a number of administrative rooms, an approximation of 550 doors is used. Dimensions of a standar assumed to be 1,981 x 0,610 m and include wooden door frame. Souce: https://www.jbkind.com/info-centre/standard-door-sizes. Assumed service life of 40 years. Source: Cobut et al. 2015. The environmental footprint of interior wood doors in non-residential buildings - part 1: life cycle assessment. Journal of Cleaner Production, 109, 232-246. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to used door, inner, wood.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). This flow represents ceramic washing basin and ceramic toilet seat. The hotel has 500 washing basins, 500 toilet seats and 163 bath tubes. Washing basins are assumed to weigh 15kg (information taken from IKEA (2018) for the product "TÖRNVIKEN Countertop wash-basin", source retrieved from: http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/products/washstands-taps/wash-basins/t%C3%B6rnviken-countertop-wash-basin-white-art-90291518/, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Toilet seats are assumed to weigh 35kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product "COOKE & LEWIS FABIENNE CLOSE-COUPLED TOILET WITH SOFT CLOSE SEAT", source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-fabienne-close-coupled-toilet-with-soft-close-seat/1142804_BQ.prd?B/R_Toilets_C_CT, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Bath tubes are assumed to weigh 33kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product COOKE & LEWIS CONWAY STEEL RECTANGULAR STRAIGHT BATH (L)1700MM (W)700MM, source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-conway-steel-rectangular-straight-bath-l-1700mm-w-700mm/194437_BQ.prd, accessed 23 March 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste.

The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Combined of all instances of use across the building structure, walls and ceiling. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. Assumed thickiness of glass wool 100 mm. Source: Knauf Insulation 2018. Knauf Insulation. Available from: http://www.knaufinsulation.co.uk/products/glass-mineral-wool-rolls/loft-insulation-rolls/earthwool-loft-roll-44 Accessed 16 March 2018. The density of glass wool is assumed to be 40 kg/m3 based on the specifications in ecoinvent dataset "glass wool mat production, CH 2000" accessed 22 Janaury 2018. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to waste glass.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Combined of all instances of use across the building floor and roof. Assuming 12.3 kg of tiles is required to cover 1 m2 of floor area. Source:  Victoria Plumbing 2018. British ceramic tile. Available from: https://victoriaplum.com/product/british-ceramic-tile-metro-bevel-white-gloss-tile-100mm-x-200mm Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of 5 years for floor ceramic tile which is equivalent to the period of major refurbishments in hotels. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19(17-18), 1917-1930. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to insert waste.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here the floor material. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). No data on the type of flooring was provided by the case study hotel so PVC was used as proxy. This is because PVC flooring is most cost-effective for hotels. Source: Mikulski 2015. TOP HOSPITALITY FLOORING OPTIONS FOR HOTELS. Available from: http://www.businessflooring.net/blog/top-hospitality-flooring-options-for-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls.Assumed density of PVC 2.3 kg/m2. Source: The colour flooring company 2018. VINYL FLOORING TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS. Available from: https://www.colourflooring.co.uk/pages/vinyl-flooring-technical-specifications Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of PVC floors is 40 years. Source: Bowyer et al. 2009. LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENT OF FLOORING MATERIALS A GUIDE TO INTELLIGENT SELECTION. Doviteil Partners. Available from: http://www.dovetailinc.org/report_pdfs/2009/dovetailfloors0809.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018.  In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to waste PVC.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Assuming that 0.5 kl per 1 m2 of floor area (AFA) is required in building construction. Source: Crawford et al. 2005. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. Value double checked in McCormack, et al. 2007.

Reference:

Crawford, Robert and Treloar, Graham 2005, An assessment of the energy and water embodied in commercial building construction, in Australian Life Cycle Assessment Conference (4th : 2005 : Novotel, Sydney, N.S.W.), Australian Life Cycle Assessment Society, Sydney, N.S.W., pp. 1-10. 

McCormack, et al. 2007. Modelling direct and indirect water requirements of construction. Building research & information. 35(2), 156-162.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Represents here all aluminium parts used in construction of the building structure and walls. Combined of all instance of use across the buidling. Assumed thickness of aluminium is 12 mm. Source: Singh and Verma, 2008. Investigations for deducing wall
thickness of aluminium shell casting using three dimensional printing. Journal of Achievements in Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, 31(2), 565-569. Available from: http://jamme.acmsse.h2.pl/papers_vol31_2/31259.pdf Accessed 25 March 2018. Assumed density of aluminium is 2700 kg/m3. Source: AmBrSoft Quality Softwares 2018. Materials density table. Available from: http://www.ambrsoft.com/CalcPhysics/Density/Table_2.htm Accessed 25 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to scrap aluminium.
